claim: Cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.

extracted_evidence.quote: BACKGROUND Quadrivalent recombinant influenza vaccines contain three times the amount of hemagglutinin protein as standard dose egg based vaccines, and the recombinant formulation is not susceptible to antigenic drift during manufacturing.
extracted_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote explicitly states that egg-based vaccines are susceptible to antigenic drift during manufacturing, which is a form of mutation that can reduce vaccine effectiveness. It directly supports the claim that mutations can develop during production in egg-based vaccines.

extracted_evidence.quote: In traditional quadrivalent standard dose inactivated influenza vaccines (SD-IIV4), chicken eggs are used to manufacture the vaccine strain.
extracted_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote establishes that standard dose influenza vaccines are produced using chicken eggs, which is relevant because the process of growing viruses in eggs is known to introduce mutations, supporting the claim about the potential for mutations during production.
